title.narrative: Promoting Small Holders Food Security and Income in Lira, Gulu and Amuru Districts of Northern Uganda through the Dairy Value Chain

description.narrative:
The 5 - year project “Promoting Small Holders Food Security and Income in Lira, Gulu and Amuru districts of Northern Uganda through the diary value chain” proposes to alleviate the problem of poverty among smallholder farmers in Northern Uganda. The project goal is to improve the livelihoods of 1,520 households directly by ensuring food security, increased household income and improved nutrition by the year 2014, through integrated interventions in dairy production, animal traction technologies, market-access/improvement and knowledge/skills application. A total of 500 dairy heifers (250 originals and 250 POGs) and 200 oxen and related implements will be distributed to participating families. Each of the 500 families will receive a dairy heifer and a set of four oxen and an ox plough will be allocated to every five neighboring families to enable them open up more agricultural land. Other households will benefit from other services which will among others include AI services, trainings in fodder management, clean milk production and handling, sustainable agriculture, environment management, business development and other business advisory services. The services will be extended to more members in the community including those who already have dairy cattle.
The project will focus on supporting smallholder producers to improve their efforts and approaches of having sufficient food and milk beyond their subsistence level. This will be by improving farmer’s ability to increase production with integrated sustainable livestock farming with a focus on value chain which is a more “market driven” approach to production. Taking on a more “economic approach”, entails having small scale livestock farmers more organized, trained and supported in the value chain processes. In order to build a successful and sustainable regional dairy sub-sector, all parts of the value chain for milk will be addressed; from cow to consumer.Project participants will in addition be given the capacity to start and manage Savings and Credit Schemes, marketing cooperatives, livestock enterprises and passing on the gift mechanism. Farmer associations will also be linked to other service providers in order to start and manage other income generating activities. This capacity strengthening will ensure continuity of the project beyond the project time."
